msItem.author: Badr al-Dīn Hilālī, d. 936/1529 (a protégé of Mīr ʿAlī Shīr Navāʾī, who was put to death on account of his Shīʿa beliefs by the Uzbek ʿUbayd) هلالى، بدر الدين
msItem.title: Dīvān Hilālī
ديوان هلالى
msItem.colophon: Ms copied during the poet’s lifetime.
msItem.note: Quite possibly the earliest manuscript of this poet's Diwan and the only one dating to his lifetime. Edition of the poet's Diwan available online: https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.286798. Information on the poet in Encyclopedia Iranica. Bankipore (Khuda Bakhsh) catalogue vol. 2p.123-4 had more. See also Ethe India Office entry 1423-31 and Rieu II, p.655-6 for BL Add 7783 which mentions the King's copy.

bibl.author: D.N. Marshall

support.material: Calligraphic album format (written in landscape, displayed as portrait). f.1r First page of indian paper (teal with gold floral patterns). f.1v gold paper with gold decorations (flowers and birds). Central panels are remargined (on their side; bottom of the calligraphic panel is now located on left side) with thick indian paper of different colours with illuminations and paintings of various sorts.

supportDesc.condition: f.3 the outer margin is coming away from the original folio (which shows clearly how the outer rulings were added on the margin). F.30 is similarly damaged at the gutter margin.

handDesc.handNote: Script: nastaʿlīq. Quality: Beautiful calligraphic nastaʿlīq. Scribe: Mīr ʿAlī al-Kātib al-Sulṭānī (“the Royal Scribe”) .

decoDesc.p: f.2r first calligraphic panel highly illuminated. Margins of central panels decorated with Safavid floral band s(?unless is Indian?) – probably added later. Intratextual illumination on first and last page early Safavid. Some of the verses (4 verses per zigzag) written diagonally on zigzag panel. Others are horizontal (3 panels; 1 verse per panel). Animals on some margins are very similar to those on the lacquer binding.

additions.p: 7 blank flyleaves at start; 8th has an erased square seal with handwritten (in Persian) “Diwan Hilali”. f.1r, inspection note (in Indian hand): seal of Shah Jahan, 2 other seals, including Polier’s, and numerous inspection notes.
additions.note: [FURTHER CODICOLOGY NOTE - TO BE PLACED ELSEWHERE THAN UNDER ADDITIONS] This album is a masterpiece. From lifetime of the poet. Calligraphy in the hand of a famous scribe who is also known to have to been responsible for the creation of albums. [REF?] Once part of Mughal royal library (seal of Shah Jahan). For more on Mīr ʿAlī’s albums and Shāhjahān’s enthusiasm for them see in particular The Emperor’s Album: Images of Mughal India by S.C. Welch.

bindingDesc.p: Lacquer binding on papier-mache with European spine (but binding is Indian).
bindingDesc.condition: Worm damage. Binding loose in some places; quires falling away.
bindingDesc.decoNote: Fabulous and naturalistic animals: rampant simurgh, dragons, fox, deer. Doublure (front) orange and gold with black-bordered turanj and two or more pendants (black, red); corner pieces have black borders; naturalistic animals: lions, deer, fox, rabbit, antelope; flowers (but few khat’i – only within the black). Back and front doublures are identical.

history.provenance: The "Pote Collection" arrived in England from India in 1790 and was divided between the Colleges of Eton and King's, Cambridge, with the first half alphabetically going to King's. Both halves of the collection are now housed in Cambridge University Library on permanent loan. Most if not all of the manuscripts had previously been owned by Colonel Antoine-Louis Henri Polier (1741–1795).
history.acquisition: Gift of Edward Ephraim Pote (d.1832) in 1788.

recordHist.source: Manuscript description based on E. G. Browne, "A supplementary hand-list of the Muhammadan manuscripts, including all those written in the Arabic character, preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge", Cambridge, 1922 and E.
